answers.author: Kathie Novak
answers.text:
I have worked with several councils on goal setting, and this is always an issue.  One helpful tool is to prepare a work plan that outlines all of the current and ongoing projects, the quarter in which the wrok will be done, and identify if/where there is any capacity.  If council wants to add items to the work plan, they must have the discussion about what is required by the goal/initiative/project, and how to make room for it in the work plan -- what can be taken off of the current plan, deferred to a later date, or decide not to add anything additional.  Not perfect, but it does help in the conversation.  Staff must also be careful not to give in and keep agreeing to do more and more, with fewer and fewer resources.

answers.author: Edward Shikada
answers.text:
Hi Pam... In San Jose, we've evolved our approach to priority setting quite a bit over the past few years. In our current environment, this has focused on prioritizing ordinances and other major policy initiatives. The Council holds priority setting sessions twice a year, most recently in October:
http://www3.sanjoseca.gov/clerk/Agenda/20121009/20121009_02.pdf
Between these sessions, the Council agenda-setting ("Rules") committee meets weekly and provides a venue for councilmembers to raise new issues and for staff to report/ recommend workplan changes. New issues are typically referred to the next priority-setting session, or there is a public discussion of time-sensitivity and reconciling with other priorities. Of course it's rarely that simple, but we try!

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is interested in learning what your agency does with respect to limiting the number of Council goals set each year in accordance with staff capacity/resources.  Or how do you maximize staff resources to meet all the Council goals? 
Any advice, suggestions, policy, etc., that you can share is appreciated!
Pamela Muse
